üéØ Why This Matters: Proper setup of vendors, materials, and equipment creates a powerful automated inventory system that saves time, money, and prevents job delays.

High-Volume, Fast-Moving (HVAC Filters):
  • Min: 50 units (2 weeks supply)
  • Max: 200 units (2 months supply)
  • Reorder: 75 units (includes safety stock)
  • Order Quantity: 125 units (volume discount)
Medium-Volume, Seasonal (AC Components):
  • Min: 10 units (1 month off-season supply)
  • Max: 50 units (1 month peak season)
  • Reorder: 20 units (adjust seasonally)
  • Order Quantity: 30 units
Low-Volume, Critical (Specialty Parts):
  • Min: 2 units (emergency backup)
  • Max: 8 units (6 months supply)
  • Reorder: 4 units
  • Order Quantity: 6 units
üîî Advanced Reorder Strategies
Reorder Trigger Methods:
1. Fixed Reorder Point:
  • Triggers when quantity drops below set level
  • Best for: Steady demand items
  • Example: Reorder copper pipe when stock hits 50 feet
2. Time-Based Reordering:
  • Reorder every X days regardless of stock level
  • Best for: Predictable usage patterns
  • Example: Order filters every 2 weeks during season
3. Economic Order Quantity (EOQ):
  • Optimal order size balancing carrying costs and order costs
  • Best for: High-value items with carrying costs
  • Example: Order quantity based on storage costs vs. volume discounts
4. Just-in-Time (JIT):
  • Order materials for specific jobs
  • Best for: Large equipment or custom items
  • Example: Order water heater when job is scheduled

üìç Multi-Location Inventory Management
Location Types & Strategies:
Main Warehouse:
  • Bulk storage of all inventory
  • Receiving and quality control
  • Replenishment source for other locations
  • Long-term storage of seasonal items
Truck Stock (Mobile Inventory):
  • Fast-moving, common repair items
  • Auto-replenishment based on route patterns
  • Limited high-value items
  • Emergency stock for after-hours calls
Job Site Staging:
  • Materials delivered for specific large projects
  • Temporary location assignment
  • Security considerations for valuable items
  • Weather protection requirements
Vendor Consignment:
  • Supplier-owned stock at your facility
  • Pay only when items are used
  • Ideal for high-value, slow-moving items
  • Vendor manages min/max levels
üí° Multi-Location Best Practices:
  • Set different min/max levels by location based on usage
  • Enable automatic transfers between locations
  • Track location-specific usage patterns
  • Implement cycle counting schedules for each location
  • Use barcode scanning for accurate location tracking
üí∞ Inventory Costing Methods
Choose the Right Costing Method:
FIFO (First In, First Out):
  • Use oldest inventory first
  • Best for: Items with expiration dates
  • Tax benefit: Lower cost of goods sold in inflationary periods
  • Example: Refrigerants, chemicals, batteries
LIFO (Last In, First Out):
  • Use newest inventory first
  • Best for: Tax optimization in inflationary periods
  • Higher cost of goods sold = lower taxes
  • Example: Copper pipe, steel materials
Weighted Average:
  • Average cost of all inventory
  • Best for: Consistent pricing to customers
  • Smooths out price fluctuations
  • Example: Common materials with price volatility
Standard Cost:
  • Fixed cost regardless of purchase price
  • Best for: Budgeting and pricing consistency
  • Requires variance tracking
  • Example: Standardized equipment models
üìä Costing Method Comparison

Example: 100 copper fittings purchased at different times

Purchase History:
‚Ä¢ Jan: 50 units @ $2.00 = $100
‚Ä¢ Mar: 30 units @ $2.50 = $75
‚Ä¢ May: 20 units @ $3.00 = $60
Total: 100 units @ $235
Cost of Goods Sold:
FIFO: $80
LIFO: $110
Avg Cost: $94
üéØ Implementation Strategy: Start with your top 20 most-used items. Perfect their inventory settings before expanding to your entire catalog. Focus on items that represent 80% of your inventory value or usage.

üìù Method 1: Direct from Job Screen
  1. Navigate to Job: Go to Jobs ‚Üí Select specific job
  2. Review Materials Needed: Check job materials and equipment list
  3. Check Inventory: ServiceTitan shows current stock levels
  4. Create PO: Click "Create Purchase Order" button
  5. Select Vendor: Choose preferred vendor for each item
  6. Adjust Quantities: Modify quantities if needed
  7. Set Delivery: Choose delivery date and location
  8. Submit: Send PO to vendor electronically or print
üìù Method 2: Bulk Purchasing from Multiple Jobs
  1. Go to Purchasing Module: Navigate to Purchasing ‚Üí Create PO
  2. Select Date Range: Choose jobs scheduled for specific period
  3. Review All Materials: System consolidates materials from all jobs
  4. Optimize Orders: Combine similar items for bulk discounts
  5. Distribute by Vendor: Split order among preferred suppliers
  6. Schedule Deliveries: Coordinate delivery timing with job schedules

üîß Technician Material Requests

  1. Open Job on Mobile: ServiceTitan mobile app
  2. Review Materials List: See what's needed vs. what's available
  3. Identify Missing Items: App highlights items not in truck stock
  4. Submit Request: Tap "Request Materials"
  5. Choose Options:
    • Rush delivery to job site
    • Pick up at supplier
    • Transfer from another truck
    • Deliver to shop for next day
  6. Add Photos/Notes: Document specific requirements
  7. Submit: Request goes to purchasing department

Service Manager ($300-$1000):
  • Major components and equipment
  • After-hours emergency purchases
  • High-priority customer situations
  • Phone approval documented
Owner/GM (Over $1000):
  • Large equipment replacements
  • Major emergency situations
  • New vendor relationships
  • Written approval required

When Bulk Purchasing Makes Sense:
  • High Usage Items: Materials used frequently (filters, pipe, wire)
  • Stable Prices: Items with predictable pricing
  • Long Shelf Life: Materials that don't expire quickly
  • Volume Discounts: Significant savings for larger quantities
  • Storage Available: Adequate space without excessive costs
ü§ù Vendor Managed Inventory (VMI)
How VMI Works:
  1. Agreement Setup: Vendor maintains minimum stock levels at your location
  2. Monitoring: Vendor tracks your usage and inventory levels
  3. Automatic Replenishment: Vendor restocks before you run out
  4. Payment on Use: You pay only when materials are consumed
  5. Performance Reviews: Regular meetings to optimize stock levels
Ideal Items for VMI:
  • High-Value Equipment: Water heaters, HVAC units
  • Fast-Moving Materials: Common pipe fittings, wire
  • Seasonal Items: Filters, refrigerants
  • Emergency Stock: Critical repair parts
VMI Benefits:
  • Reduced inventory investment and carrying costs
  • Guaranteed availability of critical items
  • Vendor expertise in demand forecasting
  • Reduced administrative purchasing overhead
  • Better cash flow (pay only when used)
üå°Ô∏è Seasonal Purchasing Strategies
Seasonal Buying Calendar:
Winter (Dec-Feb):
  • Stock up on heating components during peak demand
  • Order AC equipment for spring at off-season prices
  • Build inventory of emergency heating parts
Spring (Mar-May):
  • Purchase AC equipment before summer rush
  • Stock refrigerants before peak cooling season
  • Order bulk materials for summer construction
Summer (Jun-Aug):
  • Emergency purchasing only due to high demand
  • Order heating equipment for fall delivery
  • Plan ahead for fall maintenance season
Fall (Sep-Nov):
  • Stock heating components before winter
  • Purchase AC equipment at end-of-season prices
  • Build inventory for holiday emergencies

üìã Contract Purchasing Agreements
Types of Purchasing Contracts:
Annual Volume Contracts:
  • Commit to minimum annual purchase volume
  • Receive tiered pricing based on volume achieved
  • Ideal for: High-usage materials and equipment
  • Benefits: Predictable pricing, volume discounts
Fixed Price Contracts:
  • Lock in prices for specific period (6-12 months)
  • Protection against price increases
  • Ideal for: Volatile pricing materials (copper, steel)
  • Benefits: Budget predictability, cost control
Blanket Purchase Orders:
  • Pre-approved spending limit with vendor
  • Release orders against blanket PO as needed
  • Ideal for: Routine maintenance supplies
  • Benefits: Reduced paperwork, faster ordering
Sample Contract Terms:
HVAC Equipment Annual Contract:
Vendor: ABC Supply Company
Term: January 1 - December 31, 2024
Minimum Volume: $100,000 annually
Pricing Tiers:
  • $0-$50K: List price - 10%
  • $50K-$100K: List price - 15%
  • $100K+: List price - 20%
Payment Terms: Net 30 days
Price Protection: No increases for 12 months
Delivery: Free on orders over $500
üéØ Purchasing Best Practices:
  • Automate routine purchases through ServiceTitan workflows
  • Maintain 2-3 vendors for critical items to ensure availability
  • Review vendor performance quarterly
  • Train technicians on emergency purchasing procedures
  • Use mobile receiving to maintain accurate inventory

Common Issues & Solutions ‚ñº
üí∞ Common Pricing Problems & Solutions
‚ùå Problem: Prices too high compared to competitors
Possible Causes:
  • Markup percentages set too high
  • Material costs outdated (higher than current market)
  • Labor rates above market average
  • Double-counting overhead in pricing
‚úÖ Solutions:
  • Review and adjust markup percentages by category
  • Update material costs with current vendor pricing
  • Benchmark labor rates against local competitors
  • Audit cost structure to eliminate double-counting
‚ùå Problem: Inconsistent pricing between similar services
Possible Causes:
  • Different markup rates applied inconsistently
  • Some services missing materials or labor
  • Conflicting pricing rules
  • Manual price overrides not documented
‚úÖ Solutions:
  • Standardize markup rates by service category
  • Audit all services for complete material lists
  • Review pricing rule conflicts and priorities
  • Document all manual pricing decisions
‚ùå Problem: Dynamic pricing rules not working
Possible Causes:
  • Rule conditions not set up correctly
  • Date ranges or time conditions wrong
  • Customer types not assigned properly
  • Rule priority conflicts
‚úÖ Solutions:
  • Test rule conditions with specific date/time scenarios
  • Verify customer type assignments
  • Check rule priority settings and resolve conflicts
  • Create test estimates to validate rule application
üì¶ Material & Equipment Problems & Solutions
‚ùå Problem: Materials missing from service estimates
Possible Causes:
  • Materials not properly linked to services
  • Material categories set up incorrectly
  • Quantity calculations wrong
  • Required vs. optional settings incorrect
‚úÖ Solutions:
  • Review service-to-material connections
  • Audit material categorization and SKUs
  • Verify quantity calculations and units of measure
  • Check required/optional flags for all materials
‚ùå Problem: Equipment specifications incomplete or wrong
Possible Causes:
  • Model numbers entered incorrectly
  • Specifications not updated with manufacturer changes
  • Multiple similar models confused
  • Warranty information outdated
‚úÖ Solutions:
  • Verify all model numbers with manufacturer catalogs
  • Set up regular specification update schedule
  • Create clear naming conventions for similar models
  • Update warranty terms annually
‚ùå Problem: Inventory not updating after job completion
Possible Causes:
  • Materials not properly linked to inventory items
  • Technician not completing job properly in system
  • Manual overrides preventing automatic deduction
  • Sync issues between mobile and main system
‚úÖ Solutions:
  • Verify material-to-inventory item connections
  • Train technicians on proper job completion procedures
  • Remove unnecessary manual overrides
  • Check mobile sync settings and connectivity
üè¢ Vendor Connection Problems & Solutions
‚ùå Problem: Purchase orders not generating automatically
Possible Causes:
  • Vendor information incomplete
  • Material-vendor connections missing
  • Reorder points not set correctly
  • Automatic PO generation disabled
‚úÖ Solutions:
  • Complete all required vendor profile fields
  • Link all materials to appropriate vendors
  • Set and test reorder point triggers
  • Enable automatic PO generation in settings
‚ùå Problem: Wrong vendor pricing in purchase orders
Possible Causes:
  • Vendor pricing not updated regularly
  • Multiple vendor options conflicting
  • Contract pricing not properly configured
  • Currency or unit conversion errors
‚úÖ Solutions:
  • Establish regular vendor price update schedule
  • Set primary vendor preferences clearly
  • Configure contract pricing rules properly
  • Verify all units of measure and conversions
üîÑ Workflow & Process Problems & Solutions
‚ùå Problem: Technicians struggling with mobile app
Possible Causes:
  • Insufficient training on new system
  • Complex interface or too many steps
  • Poor mobile connectivity in field
  • App performance issues
‚úÖ Solutions:
  • Provide hands-on training with real scenarios
  • Simplify workflows and remove unnecessary steps
  • Set up offline capabilities for poor connectivity areas
  • Optimize app performance and provide device upgrades if needed
‚ùå Problem: Estimates taking too long to create
Possible Causes:
  • Too many options overwhelming users
  • Poor organization of services and materials
  • Missing templates for common jobs
  • System performance slow
‚úÖ Solutions:
  • Create service packages for common scenarios
  • Reorganize categories for logical flow
  • Build estimate templates for frequent jobs
  • Optimize system performance and provide faster hardware

  2. Tap "Request Materials"
  3. Select needed items
  4. Choose delivery method
  5. Add photo and notes
  6. Submit request

Pre-Launch Checklist (Week 1):
  • ‚úÖ Complete final testing of all workflows
  • ‚úÖ Train all staff on their respective roles
  • ‚úÖ Prepare backup procedures for issues
  • ‚úÖ Set up support contact list
  • ‚úÖ Create performance monitoring dashboards
Soft Launch (Week 2):
  • ‚úÖ Select 2-3 experienced technicians for pilot
  • ‚úÖ Use new system for 50% of jobs
  • ‚úÖ Daily check-ins to identify issues
  • ‚úÖ Document and fix problems quickly
  • ‚úÖ Gather feedback for improvements
Full Rollout (Week 3):
  • ‚úÖ All technicians start using new pricebook
  • ‚úÖ Retire old pricing methods
  • ‚úÖ Daily monitoring of key metrics
  • ‚úÖ Immediate support for any issues
  • ‚úÖ Customer communication about any changes
Optimization (Week 4):
  • ‚úÖ Analyze performance metrics
  • ‚úÖ Fine-tune pricing rules based on results
  • ‚úÖ Update training based on real-world usage
  • ‚úÖ Plan for ongoing maintenance and updates
  • ‚úÖ Celebrate success with team
üéØ Success Metrics to Track Post-Launch:
  • Efficiency: Time to create estimates (target: under 15 minutes)
  • Accuracy: Pricing consistency and error reduction
  • Profitability: Job margins meeting or exceeding targets
  • Customer Satisfaction: Feedback on pricing transparency
  • Inventory: Reduced stockouts and optimized ordering
  • Team Adoption: User satisfaction and system usage rates
dable(this)"> What is a Pricebook? ‚ñº

A pricebook in ServiceTitan is your digital catalog of everything you can sell:

  • Services: What you do (install, repair, maintain)
  • Materials: Items consumed during work
  • Equipment: Items installed and left with customer

Why it matters: Consistent pricing, faster estimates, better profitability tracking!

üè¢ Administrative Access Requirements:

üìä Business Information Needed:

‚è∞ Time Allocation:

Expected Time Investment:
  • Initial Setup: 2-4 hours for basic pricebook
  • Full Implementation: 1-2 days for comprehensive setup
  • Testing & Refinement: 1-2 weeks of real-world use
  • Team Training: 2-4 hours for technician onboarding

4Connecting Materials & Equipment to Services

Step-by-Step: Adding Items to Services ‚ñº

üîó Complete Connection Process:

Step 1
Select Service
‚Üí
Step 2
Add Materials
‚Üí
Step 3
Add Equipment
‚Üí
Step 4
Review & Test
üìù Detailed Instructions:
  1. Navigate to Service:
    • Go to Settings ‚Üí Pricebook ‚Üí Services
    • Find your service or create new one
    • Click on service name to edit
  2. Add Materials Section:
    • Scroll to "Materials" section
    • Click "+ Add Material"
    • Search by name or SKU
    • Set quantity needed for service
    • Choose if material is "Required" or "Optional"
    • Add notes about usage (e.g., "Per linear foot")
  3. Add Equipment Section:
    • Scroll to "Equipment" section
    • Click "+ Add Equipment"
    • Select from equipment catalog
    • Specify quantity (usually 1 for major equipment)
    • Set as "Required" or let customer choose options
  4. Set Quantity Logic:
    • Fixed Quantity: Always uses same amount
    • Variable Quantity: Technician enters amount needed
    • Calculated Quantity: Based on job measurements
  5. Review Totals:
    • Verify total cost calculation
    • Check profit margins
    • Ensure pricing is competitive
  6. Save and Test:
    • Save service configuration
    • Create test estimate
    • Verify all items appear correctly
üí° Pro Tips:
  • Use "Required" for essential materials that every job needs
  • Use "Optional" for upgrades or customer choices
  • Add detailed notes for technician guidance
  • Group related materials together for easier selection

5Dynamic & Customer-Specific Pricing

üéØ What You'll Learn: How to set up automatic pricing rules that adjust based on conditions like customer type, job size, time of day, or market conditions.
Dynamic Pricing Rules - Complete Setup ‚ñº

üîÑ Types of Dynamic Pricing Rules:

‚è∞ Time-Based Pricing Rules
Rule Setup Examples:
After Hours (6 PM - 8 AM weekdays):
  • Condition: Time between 18:00-08:00 AND Monday-Friday
  • Adjustment: +25% on labor rates
  • Applied to: All services
  • Example: $150 service call becomes $187.50
Weekend Premium (All day Saturday-Sunday):
  • Condition: Saturday OR Sunday
  • Adjustment: +20% on total service
  • Applied to: Non-emergency services
  • Example: $500 repair becomes $600
Holiday Premium:
  • Condition: Major holidays (Memorial Day, July 4th, Labor Day, etc.)
  • Adjustment: +50% on all charges
  • Applied to: Emergency services only
  • Example: $200 emergency call becomes $300
‚è∞ Time-Based Pricing Calculator
üìä Volume-Based Pricing
Multi-Unit Discounts:
HVAC System Discounts:
  • 2 units: 5% discount
  • 3-4 units: 8% discount
  • 5+ units: 12% discount
Service Call Bundles:
  • Annual maintenance contract: 15% off individual services
  • Multiple systems serviced same day: 10% off additional units
Material Quantity Breaks:
  • Bulk materials (over $500): 5% discount
  • Large projects (over $2000): 8% material discount
üìä Volume Discount Calculator
Subtotal: $2500
Discount: 0%
Total: $2500
üö® Emergency Pricing
Emergency Classifications:
Same-Day Service:
  • Customer needs service within 4 hours
  • Adjustment: +30% on service charges
  • Applies to: All non-emergency services converted to urgent
True Emergency:
  • Safety hazard (gas leak, electrical danger, no heat in winter)
  • Adjustment: +40% on all charges
  • Applies to: Emergency service calls only
Weather-Related Emergency:
  • During storms, extreme temperatures, or natural disasters
  • Adjustment: +25-50% based on severity
  • Applies to: All emergency services during weather events
‚ö†Ô∏è Emergency Pricing Guidelines:
  • Clearly communicate emergency rates upfront
  • Document the emergency nature in service notes
  • Consider customer relationship and repeat business
  • Follow local regulations on emergency pricing
üå°Ô∏è Seasonal Adjustments
Peak Season Pricing:
Summer Peak (June-August):
  • AC services: +15% due to high demand
  • AC installations: +20% due to equipment shortage
  • Emergency cooling: +25% additional
Winter Peak (December-February):
  • Heating services: +15% due to high demand
  • Emergency heating: +30% during cold snaps
  • Furnace installations: +10% due to scheduling
Off-Season Discounts:
  • Spring/Fall maintenance: -10% to encourage preventive service
  • System installations during slow periods: -5%
üå°Ô∏è Seasonal Pricing Calculator
üìç Location-Based Pricing
Geographic Adjustments:
Travel Distance:
  • Within 15 miles: Standard pricing
  • 15-30 miles: +$25 travel charge
  • 30-50 miles: +$50 travel charge
  • Over 50 miles: +$75 + mileage
Market Areas:
  • High-income areas: +10% on services
  • Commercial districts: +15% for business hours
  • Rural areas: +$35 for extended travel time
Difficulty Factors:
  • High-rise buildings (over 3 floors): +20%
  • Difficult access locations: +15%
  • Restricted parking areas: +$25

‚öôÔ∏è Setting Up Dynamic Rules in ServiceTitan:

  1. Navigate to Pricing Rules: Settings ‚Üí Pricebook ‚Üí Pricing Rules
  2. Create New Rule: Click "+ Add Rule"
  3. Define Conditions:
    • Time-based: Set specific hours, days, or date ranges
    • Customer-based: Select customer types or specific customers
    • Service-based: Choose which services to apply rule to
    • Location-based: Set geographic boundaries
  4. Set Pricing Adjustment:
    • Percentage increase/decrease
    • Fixed dollar amount
    • New fixed price
  5. Define Scope:
    • Apply to labor only
    • Apply to materials only
    • Apply to entire service
    • Apply to specific categories
  6. Set Priority: If multiple rules apply, which takes precedence
  7. Test Scenarios: Create test estimates to verify rule behavior
Customer-Specific Pricing - Advanced Setup ‚ñº

üë• Customer Pricing Strategy:

üè¢ Commercial Customers
Property Management Companies:
  • Volume discount: 10-15% off standard rates
  • Annual contracts: Fixed pricing for 12 months
  • Payment terms: Net 30 days
  • Priority scheduling during business hours
Small Businesses:
  • Business hours discount: 5% off (less disruption)
  • Maintenance agreements: 20% off emergency calls
  • Bulk service packages available
üè† Residential Customers

  • Service calls: 15% discount
  • Equipment installations: 10% discount
  • No trip charges
  • Priority scheduling
Senior Citizens:
  • Standard discount: 10% off services
  • Safety services: Additional discounts
  • Payment plans available
Military/First Responders:
  • Service discount: 10% off with valid ID
  • Emergency service priority
  • Flexible payment terms

üìã Setting Up Customer Types:

  1. Create Customer Categories:
    • Go to Settings ‚Üí Customers ‚Üí Customer Types
    • Add types: VIP, Commercial, Senior, Military, etc.
    • Set default discounts for each type
  2. Assign Pricing Rules:
    • Link customer types to specific pricing rules
    • Set automatic discount applications
    • Configure approval requirements for large discounts
  3. Individual Customer Overrides:
    • Set custom pricing for specific high-value customers
    • Create contract rates for repeat customers
    • Configure payment terms by customer
  4. Loyalty Program Setup:
    • Track customer purchase history
    • Automatically upgrade customers to VIP status
    • Set spending thresholds for tier advancement

üéØ Primary Vendor Strategy
Selecting Primary Vendors:
Criteria for Primary Vendor Selection:
  • Best Overall Value: Price + service + reliability
  • Consistent Availability: Stock levels and lead times
  • Geographic Coverage: Can deliver to all your service areas
  • Credit Terms: Favorable payment arrangements
  • Volume Discounts: Better pricing for bulk orders

  • HVAC: Ferguson HVAC Supply (equipment), Johnstone Supply (parts)
  • Plumbing: Ferguson Plumbing, Local plumbing supply house
  • Electrical: Graybar Electric, Local electrical wholesaler

üîÑ Backup Vendor Strategy
Why You Need Backup Vendors:
  • Stock Outages: Primary vendor runs out of critical items
  • Emergency Needs: Faster delivery when customer can't wait
  • Price Competition: Leverage for better primary vendor pricing
  • Quality Issues: Alternative source when problems arise
  • Geographic Coverage: Better local availability
Backup Vendor Selection Criteria:
  • Fast Delivery: Same-day or next-day availability
  • Local Presence: Will-call or nearby locations
  • Emergency Support: After-hours or weekend access
  • No Minimum Orders: Can buy single items when needed
Common Backup Vendor Examples:
Big Box Stores (Emergency/Small Quantities):
  • Home Depot - Basic materials, some equipment
  • Lowe's - Similar coverage to Home Depot
  • Menards - Regional availability with pro services
Local Suppliers (Relationship/Speed):
  • Local HVAC supply houses - Personal relationships
  • Electrical wholesalers - Specialized inventory
  • Plumbing suppliers - Local expertise
Online/Specialty (Hard-to-find items):
  • Amazon Business - Fast delivery, unique items
  • Grainger - Industrial supplies and tools
  • Specialty manufacturers - Direct from source
üéØ Specialized Vendor Categories

Specialized Services:
  • Refrigerant Suppliers: Bulk refrigerant and recovery

A pricebook in ServiceTitan is your digital catalog of everything you can sell:

  • Services: What you do (install, repair, maintain)
  • Materials: Items consumed during work
  • Equipment: Items installed and left with customer

Why it matters: Consistent pricing, faster estimates, better profitability tracking!

4Connecting Materials & Equipment to Services

Step-by-Step: Adding Items to Services ‚ñº

üîó Complete Connection Process:

Step 1
Select Service
‚Üí
Step 2
Add Materials
‚Üí
Step 3
Add Equipment
‚Üí
Step 4
Review & Test
üìù Detailed Instructions:
  1. Navigate to Service:
    • Go to Settings ‚Üí Pricebook ‚Üí Services
    • Find your service or create new one
    • Click on service name to edit
  2. Add Materials Section:
    • Scroll to "Materials" section
    • Click "+ Add Material"
    • Search by name or SKU
    • Set quantity needed for service
    • Choose if material is "Required" or "Optional"
    • Add notes about usage (e.g., "Per linear foot")
  3. Add Equipment Section:
    • Scroll to "Equipment" section
    • Click "+ Add Equipment"
    • Select from equipment catalog
    • Specify quantity (usually 1 for major equipment)
    • Set as "Required" or let customer choose options
  4. Set Quantity Logic:
    • Fixed Quantity: Always uses same amount
    • Variable Quantity: Technician enters amount needed
    • Calculated Quantity: Based on job measurements
  5. Review Totals:
    • Verify total cost calculation
    • Check profit margins
    • Ensure pricing is competitive
  6. Save and Test:
    • Save service configuration
    • Create test estimate
    • Verify all items appear correctly
üí° Pro Tips:
  • Use "Required" for essential materials that every job needs
  • Use "Optional" for upgrades or customer choices
  • Add detailed notes for technician guidance
  • Group related materials together for easier selection

5Dynamic & Customer-Specific Pricing

üéØ What You'll Learn: How to set up automatic pricing rules that adjust based on conditions like customer type, job size, time of day, or market conditions.
Dynamic Pricing Rules - Complete Setup ‚ñº

üîÑ Types of Dynamic Pricing Rules:

‚è∞ Time-Based Pricing Rules
Rule Setup Examples:
After Hours (6 PM - 8 AM weekdays):
  • Condition: Time between 18:00-08:00 AND Monday-Friday
  • Adjustment: +25% on labor rates
  • Applied to: All services
  • Example: $150 service call becomes $187.50
Weekend Premium (All day Saturday-Sunday):
  • Condition: Saturday OR Sunday
  • Adjustment: +20% on total service
  • Applied to: Non-emergency services
  • Example: $500 repair becomes $600
Holiday Premium:
  • Condition: Major holidays (Memorial Day, July 4th, Labor Day, etc.)
  • Adjustment: +50% on all charges
  • Applied to: Emergency services only
  • Example: $200 emergency call becomes $300
‚è∞ Time-Based Pricing Calculator
üìä Volume-Based Pricing
Multi-Unit Discounts:
HVAC System Discounts:
  • 2 units: 5% discount
  • 3-4 units: 8% discount
  • 5+ units: 12% discount
Service Call Bundles:
  • Annual maintenance contract: 15% off individual services
  • Multiple systems serviced same day: 10% off additional units
Material Quantity Breaks:
  • Bulk materials (over $500): 5% discount
  • Large projects (over $2000): 8% material discount
üìä Volume Discount Calculator
Subtotal: $2500
Discount: 0%
Total: $2500
üö® Emergency Pricing
Emergency Classifications:
Same-Day Service:
  • Customer needs service within 4 hours
  • Adjustment: +30% on service charges
  • Applies to: All non-emergency services converted to urgent
True Emergency:
  • Safety hazard (gas leak, electrical danger, no heat in winter)
  • Adjustment: +40% on all charges
  • Applies to: Emergency service calls only
Weather-Related Emergency:
  • During storms, extreme temperatures, or natural disasters
  • Adjustment: +25-50% based on severity
  • Applies to: All emergency services during weather events
‚ö†Ô∏è Emergency Pricing Guidelines:
  • Clearly communicate emergency rates upfront
  • Document the emergency nature in service notes
  • Consider customer relationship and repeat business
  • Follow local regulations on emergency pricing
üå°Ô∏è Seasonal Adjustments
Peak Season Pricing:
Summer Peak (June-August):
  • AC services: +15% due to high demand
  • AC installations: +20% due to equipment shortage
  • Emergency cooling: +25% additional
Winter Peak (December-February):
  • Heating services: +15% due to high demand
  • Emergency heating: +30% during cold snaps
  • Furnace installations: +10% due to scheduling
Off-Season Discounts:
  • Spring/Fall maintenance: -10% to encourage preventive service
  • System installations during slow periods: -5%
üå°Ô∏è Seasonal Pricing Calculator
üìç Location-Based Pricing
Geographic Adjustments:
Travel Distance:
  • Within 15 miles: Standard pricing
  • 15-30 miles: +$25 travel charge
  • 30-50 miles: +$50 travel charge
  • Over 50 miles: +$75 + mileage
Market Areas:
  • High-income areas: +10% on services
  • Commercial districts: +15% for business hours
  • Rural areas: +$35 for extended travel time
Difficulty Factors:
  • High-rise buildings (over 3 floors): +20%
  • Difficult access locations: +15%
  • Restricted parking areas: +$25

‚öôÔ∏è Setting Up Dynamic Rules in ServiceTitan:

  1. Navigate to Pricing Rules: Settings ‚Üí Pricebook ‚Üí Pricing Rules
  2. Create New Rule: Click "+ Add Rule"
  3. Define Conditions:
    • Time-based: Set specific hours, days, or date ranges
    • Customer-based: Select customer types or specific customers
    • Service-based: Choose which services to apply rule to
    • Location-based: Set geographic boundaries
  4. Set Pricing Adjustment:
    • Percentage increase/decrease
    • Fixed dollar amount
    • New fixed price
  5. Define Scope:
    • Apply to labor only
    • Apply to materials only
    • Apply to entire service
    • Apply to specific categories
  6. Set Priority: If multiple rules apply, which takes precedence
  7. Test Scenarios: Create test estimates to verify rule behavior
Customer-Specific Pricing - Advanced Setup ‚ñº

üë• Customer Pricing Strategy:

üè¢ Commercial Customers
Property Management Companies:
  • Volume discount: 10-15% off standard rates
  • Annual contracts: Fixed pricing for 12 months
  • Payment terms: Net 30 days
  • Priority scheduling during business hours
Small Businesses:
  • Business hours discount: 5% off (less disruption)
  • Maintenance agreements: 20% off emergency calls
  • Bulk service packages available
üè† Residential Customers
VIP/Maintenance Members:
  • Service calls: 15% discount
  • Equipment installations: 10% discount
  • No trip charges
  • Priority scheduling
Senior Citizens:
  • Standard discount: 10% off services
  • Safety services: Additional discounts
  • Payment plans available
Military/First Responders:
  • Service discount: 10% off with valid ID
  • Emergency service priority
  • Flexible payment terms

üìã Setting Up Customer Types:

  1. Create Customer Categories:
    • Go to Settings ‚Üí Customers ‚Üí Customer Types
    • Add types: VIP, Commercial, Senior, Military, etc.
    • Set default discounts for each type
  2. Assign Pricing Rules:
    • Link customer types to specific pricing rules
    • Set automatic discount applications
    • Configure approval requirements for large discounts
  3. Individual Customer Overrides:
    • Set custom pricing for specific high-value customers
    • Create contract rates for repeat customers
    • Configure payment terms by customer
  4. Loyalty Program Setup:
    • Track customer purchase history
    • Automatically upgrade customers to VIP status
    • Set spending thresholds for tier advancement

  • Document all customer agreements in writing
  • Review customer pricing annually
  • Track profitability by customer type

  • Set clear approval processes for custom pricing
‚ö†Ô∏è Important Considerations:
  • Test all pricing rules thoroughly before going live
  • Ensure rules don't conflict with each other
  • Monitor profitability impact of all discounts
  • Train technicians on explaining pricing to customers
  • Review and adjust rules based on market feedback

üéØ Primary Vendor Strategy
Selecting Primary Vendors:
Criteria for Primary Vendor Selection:
  • Best Overall Value: Price + service + reliability
  • Consistent Availability: Stock levels and lead times
  • Geographic Coverage: Can deliver to all your service areas
  • Credit Terms: Favorable payment arrangements
  • Volume Discounts: Better pricing for bulk orders

üîÑ Backup Vendor Strategy
Why You Need Backup Vendors:
  • Stock Outages: Primary vendor runs out of critical items
  • Emergency Needs: Faster delivery when customer can't wait
  • Price Competition: Leverage for better primary vendor pricing
  • Quality Issues: Alternative source when problems arise
  • Geographic Coverage: Better local availability
Backup Vendor Selection Criteria:
  • Fast Delivery: Same-day or next-day availability
  • Local Presence: Will-call or nearby locations
  • Emergency Support: After-hours or weekend access
  • No Minimum Orders: Can buy single items when needed
Common Backup Vendor Examples:
Big Box Stores (Emergency/Small Quantities):
  • Home Depot - Basic materials, some equipment
  • Lowe's - Similar coverage to Home Depot
  • Menards - Regional availability with pro services
Local Suppliers (Relationship/Speed):
  • Local HVAC supply houses - Personal relationships
  • Electrical wholesalers - Specialized inventory
  • Plumbing suppliers - Local expertise
Online/Specialty (Hard-to-find items):
  • Amazon Business - Fast delivery, unique items
  • Grainger - Industrial supplies and tools
  • Specialty manufacturers - Direct from source
üéØ Specialized Vendor Categories
Equipment-Specific Vendors:
HVAC Equipment:
  • Carrier/Bryant: ICP parts and equipment
  • Trane: Direct from manufacturer
  • Rheem/Ruud: Factory parts and warranties
  • Goodman: Value equipment lines
Specialized Services:
  • Refrigerant Suppliers: Bulk refrigerant and recovery
  • Motor Shops: Custom motor repair and rewind
  • Fabrication Shops: Custom ductwork and sheet metal
  • Controls Specialists: Building automation systems
Service-Specific Vendor Setup:
Emergency Services:
  • 24/7 vendor hotlines
  • After-hours pickup arrangements

  • Premium pricing acknowledged
Large Projects:
  • Project-specific pricing
  • Staged delivery schedules

What is a Pricebook? ‚ñº

A pricebook in ServiceTitan is your digital catalog of everything you can sell:

  • Services: What you do (install, repair, maintain)
  • Materials: Items consumed during work
  • Equipment: Items installed and left with customer

Why it matters: Consistent pricing, faster estimates, better profitability tracking!

üìä Business Information Needed:

  • Initial Setup: 2-4 hours for basic pricebook
  • Full Implementation: 1-2 days for comprehensive setup
  • Testing & Refinement: 1-2 weeks of real-world use
  • Team Training: 2-4 hours for technician onboarding

üìù Creating Categories in ServiceTitan:

  1. Navigate: Settings ‚Üí Pricebook ‚Üí Materials
  2. Add Category: Click "+ Add Category"
  3. Name Category: Use descriptive names (e.g., "HVAC - Refrigerants")
  4. Set Hierarchy: Create main categories, then subcategories
  5. Add Materials: Click "+ Add Material" within category
  6. Configure Details: SKU, description, unit of measure, cost
  7. Set Pricing: Cost markup or selling price
  8. Link Vendors: Connect to supplier information

4Connecting Materials & Equipment to Services

Step-by-Step: Adding Items to Services ‚ñº

üîó Complete Connection Process:

Step 1
Select Service
‚Üí
Step 2
Add Materials
‚Üí
Step 3
Add Equipment
‚Üí
Step 4
Review & Test
üìù Detailed Instructions:
  1. Navigate to Service:
    • Go to Settings ‚Üí Pricebook ‚Üí Services
    • Find your service or create new one
    • Click on service name to edit
  2. Add Materials Section:
    • Scroll to "Materials" section
    • Click "+ Add Material"
    • Search by name or SKU
    • Set quantity needed for service
    • Choose if material is "Required" or "Optional"
    • Add notes about usage (e.g., "Per linear foot")
  3. Add Equipment Section:
    • Scroll to "Equipment" section
    • Click "+ Add Equipment"
    • Select from equipment catalog
    • Specify quantity (usually 1 for major equipment)
    • Set as "Required" or let customer choose options
  4. Set Quantity Logic:
    • Fixed Quantity: Always uses same amount
    • Variable Quantity: Technician enters amount needed
    • Calculated Quantity: Based on job measurements
  5. Review Totals:
    • Verify total cost calculation
    • Check profit margins
    • Ensure pricing is competitive
  6. Save and Test:
    • Save service configuration
    • Create test estimate
    • Verify all items appear correctly
üí° Pro Tips:
  • Use "Required" for essential materials that every job needs
  • Use "Optional" for upgrades or customer choices
  • Add detailed notes for technician guidance
  • Group related materials together for easier selection

5Dynamic & Customer-Specific Pricing

üéØ What You'll Learn: How to set up automatic pricing rules that adjust based on conditions like customer type, job size, time of day, or market conditions.
Dynamic Pricing Rules - Complete Setup ‚ñº

üîÑ Types of Dynamic Pricing Rules:

‚è∞ Time-Based Pricing Rules
Rule Setup Examples:
After Hours (6 PM - 8 AM weekdays):
  • Condition: Time between 18:00-08:00 AND Monday-Friday
  • Adjustment: +25% on labor rates
  • Applied to: All services
  • Example: $150 service call becomes $187.50
Weekend Premium (All day Saturday-Sunday):
  • Condition: Saturday OR Sunday
  • Adjustment: +20% on total service
  • Applied to: Non-emergency services
  • Example: $500 repair becomes $600
Holiday Premium:
  • Condition: Major holidays (Memorial Day, July 4th, Labor Day, etc.)
  • Adjustment: +50% on all charges
  • Applied to: Emergency services only
  • Example: $200 emergency call becomes $300
‚è∞ Time-Based Pricing Calculator
üìä Volume-Based Pricing
Multi-Unit Discounts:
HVAC System Discounts:
  • 2 units: 5% discount
  • 3-4 units: 8% discount
  • 5+ units: 12% discount
Service Call Bundles:
  • Annual maintenance contract: 15% off individual services
  • Multiple systems serviced same day: 10% off additional units
Material Quantity Breaks:
  • Bulk materials (over $500): 5% discount
  • Large projects (over $2000): 8% material discount
üìä Volume Discount Calculator
Subtotal: $2500
Discount: 0%
Total: $2500
üö® Emergency Pricing
Emergency Classifications:
Same-Day Service:
  • Customer needs service within 4 hours
  • Adjustment: +30% on service charges
  • Applies to: All non-emergency services converted to urgent
True Emergency:
  • Safety hazard (gas leak, electrical danger, no heat in winter)
  • Adjustment: +40% on all charges
  • Applies to: Emergency service calls only
Weather-Related Emergency:
  • During storms, extreme temperatures, or natural disasters
  • Adjustment: +25-50% based on severity
  • Applies to: All emergency services during weather events
‚ö†Ô∏è Emergency Pricing Guidelines:
  • Clearly communicate emergency rates upfront
  • Document the emergency nature in service notes
  • Consider customer relationship and repeat business
  • Follow local regulations on emergency pricing
üå°Ô∏è Seasonal Adjustments
Peak Season Pricing:
Summer Peak (June-August):
  • AC services: +15% due to high demand
  • AC installations: +20% due to equipment shortage
  • Emergency cooling: +25% additional
Winter Peak (December-February):
  • Heating services: +15% due to high demand
  • Emergency heating: +30% during cold snaps
  • Furnace installations: +10% due to scheduling
Off-Season Discounts:
  • Spring/Fall maintenance: -10% to encourage preventive service
  • System installations during slow periods: -5%
üå°Ô∏è Seasonal Pricing Calculator
üìç Location-Based Pricing
Geographic Adjustments:
Travel Distance:
  • Within 15 miles: Standard pricing
  • 15-30 miles: +$25 travel charge
  • 30-50 miles: +$50 travel charge
  • Over 50 miles: +$75 + mileage
Market Areas:
  • High-income areas: +10% on services
  • Commercial districts: +15% for business hours
  • Rural areas: +$35 for extended travel time
Difficulty Factors:
  • High-rise buildings (over 3 floors): +20%
  • Difficult access locations: +15%
  • Restricted parking areas: +$25

‚öôÔ∏è Setting Up Dynamic Rules in ServiceTitan:

  1. Navigate to Pricing Rules: Settings ‚Üí Pricebook ‚Üí Pricing Rules
  2. Create New Rule: Click "+ Add Rule"
  3. Define Conditions:
    • Time-based: Set specific hours, days, or date ranges
    • Customer-based: Select customer types or specific customers
    • Service-based: Choose which services to apply rule to
    • Location-based: Set geographic boundaries
  4. Set Pricing Adjustment:
    • Percentage increase/decrease
    • Fixed dollar amount
    • New fixed price
  5. Define Scope:
    • Apply to labor only
    • Apply to materials only
    • Apply to entire service
    • Apply to specific categories
  6. Set Priority: If multiple rules apply, which takes precedence
  7. Test Scenarios: Create test estimates to verify rule behavior
Customer-Specific Pricing - Advanced Setup ‚ñº

üë• Customer Pricing Strategy:

üè¢ Commercial Customers
Property Management Companies:
  • Volume discount: 10-15% off standard rates
  • Annual contracts: Fixed pricing for 12 months
  • Payment terms: Net 30 days
  • Priority scheduling during business hours
Small Businesses:
  • Business hours discount: 5% off (less disruption)
  • Maintenance agreements: 20% off emergency calls
  • Bulk service packages available
üè† Residential Customers
VIP/Maintenance Members:
  • Service calls: 15% discount
  • Equipment installations: 10% discount
  • No trip charges
  • Priority scheduling
Senior Citizens:
  • Standard discount: 10% off services
  • Safety services: Additional discounts
  • Payment plans available
Military/First Responders:
  • Service discount: 10% off with valid ID
  • Emergency service priority
  • Flexible payment terms

üìã Setting Up Customer Types:

  1. Create Customer Categories:
    • Go to Settings ‚Üí Customers ‚Üí Customer Types
    • Add types: VIP, Commercial, Senior, Military, etc.
    • Set default discounts for each type
  2. Assign Pricing Rules:
    • Link customer types to specific pricing rules
    • Set automatic discount applications
    • Configure approval requirements for large discounts
  3. Individual Customer Overrides:
    • Set custom pricing for specific high-value customers
    • Create contract rates for repeat customers
    • Configure payment terms by customer
  4. Loyalty Program Setup:
    • Track customer purchase history
    • Automatically upgrade customers to VIP status
    • Set spending thresholds for tier advancement

üí° Best Practices:
  • Document all customer agreements in writing
  • Review customer pricing annually
  • Track profitability by customer type
  • Train staff on when to apply discounts
  • Set clear approval processes for custom pricing
‚ö†Ô∏è Important Considerations:
  • Test all pricing rules thoroughly before going live
  • Ensure rules don't conflict with each other
  • Monitor profitability impact of all discounts
  • Train technicians on explaining pricing to customers
  • Review and adjust rules based on market feedback

Connecting Vendors to Materials/Equipment - Advanced ‚ñº

üîó Advanced Vendor Connection Strategies:

üéØ Primary Vendor Strategy
Selecting Primary Vendors:
Criteria for Primary Vendor Selection:
  • Best Overall Value: Price + service + reliability
  • Consistent Availability: Stock levels and lead times
  • Geographic Coverage: Can deliver to all your service areas
  • Credit Terms: Favorable payment arrangements
  • Volume Discounts: Better pricing for bulk orders
Primary Vendor Examples by Trade:
  • HVAC: Ferguson HVAC Supply (equipment), Johnstone Supply (parts)
  • Plumbing: Ferguson Plumbing, Local plumbing supply house
  • Electrical: Graybar Electric, Local electrical wholesaler
  • General: Home Depot Pro, Menards Pro
üí∞ Vendor Cost Comparison Tool
Vendor A (Primary)

üìä Total Cost Comparison:
üîÑ Backup Vendor Strategy
Why You Need Backup Vendors:
  • Stock Outages: Primary vendor runs out of critical items
  • Emergency Needs: Faster delivery when customer can't wait
  • Price Competition: Leverage for better primary vendor pricing
  • Quality Issues: Alternative source when problems arise
  • Geographic Coverage: Better local availability
Backup Vendor Selection Criteria:
  • Fast Delivery: Same-day or next-day availability
  • Local Presence: Will-call or nearby locations
  • Emergency Support: After-hours or weekend access
  • No Minimum Orders: Can buy single items when needed
Common Backup Vendor Examples:
Big Box Stores (Emergency/Small Quantities):
  • Home Depot - Basic materials, some equipment
  • Lowe's - Similar coverage to Home Depot
  • Menards - Regional availability with pro services
Local Suppliers (Relationship/Speed):
  • Local HVAC supply houses - Personal relationships
  • Electrical wholesalers - Specialized inventory
  • Plumbing suppliers - Local expertise
Online/Specialty (Hard-to-find items):
  • Amazon Business - Fast delivery, unique items
  • Grainger - Industrial supplies and tools
  • Specialty manufacturers - Direct from source
üéØ Specialized Vendor Categories
Equipment-Specific Vendors:
HVAC Equipment:
  • Carrier/Bryant: ICP parts and equipment
  • Trane: Direct from manufacturer
  • Rheem/Ruud: Factory parts and warranties
  • Goodman: Value equipment lines
Specialized Services:
  • Refrigerant Suppliers: Bulk refrigerant and recovery
  • Motor Shops: Custom motor repair and rewind
  • Fabrication Shops: Custom ductwork and sheet metal
  • Controls Specialists: Building automation systems
Service-Specific Vendor Setup:
Emergency Services:
  • 24/7 vendor hotlines
  • After-hours pickup arrangements
  • Emergency stock agreements
  • Premium pricing acknowledged
Large Projects:
  • Project-specific pricing
  • Staged delivery schedules
  • Job site delivery coordination
  • Extended payment terms
üìà Vendor Performance Tracking
Key Performance Indicators (KPIs):
Delivery Performance:
  • On-Time Delivery Rate: Target: 95%+ on-time
  • Order Accuracy: Target: 98%+ correct items
  • Damage Rate: Target: Less than 1% damaged goods
  • Lead Time Consistency: Promised vs. actual delivery
Financial Performance:
  • Price Competitiveness: Regular market comparisons
  • Payment Terms: Discount opportunities and flexibility
  • Invoice Accuracy: Billing errors and corrections
  • Volume Discounts: Achievement of tier pricing
Service Quality:
  • Communication: Response time to inquiries
  • Problem Resolution: Time to resolve issues
  • Product Knowledge: Staff expertise and helpfulness
  • Account Management: Proactive relationship management

What is a Pricebook? ‚ñº

A pricebook in ServiceTitan is your digital catalog of everything you can sell:

  • Services: What you do (install, repair, maintain)
  • Materials: Items consumed during work
  • Equipment: Items installed and left with customer

Why it matters: Consistent pricing, faster estimates, better profitability tracking!

Before You Start - Preparation Checklist ‚ñº

üè¢ Administrative Access Requirements:

üìä Business Information Needed:

‚è∞ Time Allocation:

Expected Time Investment:
  • Initial Setup: 2-4 hours for basic pricebook
  • Full Implementation: 1-2 days for comprehensive setup
  • Testing & Refinement: 1-2 weeks of real-world use
  • Team Training: 2-4 hours for technician onboarding

4Connecting Materials & Equipment to Services

Step-by-Step: Adding Items to Services ‚ñº

üîó Complete Connection Process:

Step 1
Select Service
‚Üí
Step 2
Add Materials
‚Üí
Step 3
Add Equipment
‚Üí
Step 4
Review & Test
üìù Detailed Instructions:
  1. Navigate to Service:
    • Go to Settings ‚Üí Pricebook ‚Üí Services
    • Find your service or create new one
    • Click on service name to edit
  2. Add Materials Section:
    • Scroll to "Materials" section
    • Click "+ Add Material"
    • Search by name or SKU
    • Set quantity needed for service
    • Choose if material is "Required" or "Optional"
    • Add notes about usage (e.g., "Per linear foot")
  3. Add Equipment Section:
    • Scroll to "Equipment" section
    • Click "+ Add Equipment"
    • Select from equipment catalog
    • Specify quantity (usually 1 for major equipment)
    • Set as "Required" or let customer choose options
  4. Set Quantity Logic:
    • Fixed Quantity: Always uses same amount
    • Variable Quantity: Technician enters amount needed
    • Calculated Quantity: Based on job measurements
  5. Review Totals:
    • Verify total cost calculation
    • Check profit margins
    • Ensure pricing is competitive
  6. Save and Test:
    • Save service configuration
    • Create test estimate
    • Verify all items appear correctly
üí° Pro Tips:
  • Use "Required" for essential materials that every job needs
  • Use "Optional" for upgrades or customer choices
  • Add detailed notes for technician guidance
  • Group related materials together for easier selection

5Dynamic & Customer-Specific Pricing

üéØ What You'll Learn: How to set up automatic pricing rules that adjust based on conditions like customer type, job size, time of day, or market conditions.
Dynamic Pricing Rules - Complete Setup ‚ñº

üîÑ Types of Dynamic Pricing Rules:

‚è∞ Time-Based Pricing Rules
Rule Setup Examples:
After Hours (6 PM - 8 AM weekdays):
  • Condition: Time between 18:00-08:00 AND Monday-Friday
  • Adjustment: +25% on labor rates
  • Applied to: All services
  • Example: $150 service call becomes $187.50
Weekend Premium (All day Saturday-Sunday):
  • Condition: Saturday OR Sunday
  • Adjustment: +20% on total service
  • Applied to: Non-emergency services
  • Example: $500 repair becomes $600
Holiday Premium:
  • Condition: Major holidays (Memorial Day, July 4th, Labor Day, etc.)
  • Adjustment: +50% on all charges
  • Applied to: Emergency services only
  • Example: $200 emergency call becomes $300
‚è∞ Time-Based Pricing Calculator
üìä Volume-Based Pricing
Multi-Unit Discounts:
HVAC System Discounts:
  • 2 units: 5% discount
  • 3-4 units: 8% discount
  • 5+ units: 12% discount
Service Call Bundles:
  • Annual maintenance contract: 15% off individual services
  • Multiple systems serviced same day: 10% off additional units
Material Quantity Breaks:
  • Bulk materials (over $500): 5% discount
  • Large projects (over $2000): 8% material discount
üìä Volume Discount Calculator
Subtotal: $2500
Discount: 0%
Total: $2500
üö® Emergency Pricing
Emergency Classifications:
Same-Day Service:
  • Customer needs service within 4 hours
  • Adjustment: +30% on service charges
  • Applies to: All non-emergency services converted to urgent
True Emergency:
  • Safety hazard (gas leak, electrical danger, no heat in winter)
  • Adjustment: +40% on all charges
  • Applies to: Emergency service calls only
Weather-Related Emergency:
  • During storms, extreme temperatures, or natural disasters
  • Adjustment: +25-50% based on severity
  • Applies to: All emergency services during weather events
‚ö†Ô∏è Emergency Pricing Guidelines:
  • Clearly communicate emergency rates upfront
  • Document the emergency nature in service notes
  • Consider customer relationship and repeat business
  • Follow local regulations on emergency pricing
üå°Ô∏è Seasonal Adjustments
Peak Season Pricing:
Summer Peak (June-August):
  • AC services: +15% due to high demand
  • AC installations: +20% due to equipment shortage
  • Emergency cooling: +25% additional
Winter Peak (December-February):
  • Heating services: +15% due to high demand
  • Emergency heating: +30% during cold snaps
  • Furnace installations: +10% due to scheduling
Off-Season Discounts:
  • Spring/Fall maintenance: -10% to encourage preventive service
  • System installations during slow periods: -5%
üå°Ô∏è Seasonal Pricing Calculator
üìç Location-Based Pricing
Geographic Adjustments:
Travel Distance:
  • Within 15 miles: Standard pricing
  • 15-30 miles: +$25 travel charge
  • 30-50 miles: +$50 travel charge
  • Over 50 miles: +$75 + mileage
Market Areas:
  • High-income areas: +10% on services
  • Commercial districts: +15% for business hours
  • Rural areas: +$35 for extended travel time
Difficulty Factors:
  • High-rise buildings (over 3 floors): +20%
  • Difficult access locations: +15%
  • Restricted parking areas: +$25

‚öôÔ∏è Setting Up Dynamic Rules in ServiceTitan:

  1. Navigate to Pricing Rules: Settings ‚Üí Pricebook ‚Üí Pricing Rules
  2. Create New Rule: Click "+ Add Rule"
  3. Define Conditions:
    • Time-based: Set specific hours, days, or date ranges
    • Customer-based: Select customer types or specific customers
    • Service-based: Choose which services to apply rule to
    • Location-based: Set geographic boundaries
  4. Set Pricing Adjustment:
    • Percentage increase/decrease
    • Fixed dollar amount
    • New fixed price
  5. Define Scope:
    • Apply to labor only
    • Apply to materials only
    • Apply to entire service
    • Apply to specific categories
  6. Set Priority: If multiple rules apply, which takes precedence
  7. Test Scenarios: Create test estimates to verify rule behavior
Customer-Specific Pricing - Advanced Setup ‚ñº

üë• Customer Pricing Strategy:

üè¢ Commercial Customers
Property Management Companies:
  • Volume discount: 10-15% off standard rates
  • Annual contracts: Fixed pricing for 12 months
  • Payment terms: Net 30 days
  • Priority scheduling during business hours
Small Businesses:
  • Business hours discount: 5% off (less disruption)
  • Maintenance agreements: 20% off emergency calls
  • Bulk service packages available
üè† Residential Customers
VIP/Maintenance Members:
  • Service calls: 15% discount
  • Equipment installations: 10% discount
  • No trip charges
  • Priority scheduling
Senior Citizens:
  • Standard discount: 10% off services
  • Safety services: Additional discounts
  • Payment plans available
Military/First Responders:
  • Service discount: 10% off with valid ID
  • Emergency service priority
  • Flexible payment terms

üìã Setting Up Customer Types:

  1. Create Customer Categories:
    • Go to Settings ‚Üí Customers ‚Üí Customer Types
    • Add types: VIP, Commercial, Senior, Military, etc.
    • Set default discounts for each type
  2. Assign Pricing Rules:
    • Link customer types to specific pricing rules
    • Set automatic discount applications
    • Configure approval requirements for large discounts
  3. Individual Customer Overrides:
    • Set custom pricing for specific high-value customers
    • Create contract rates for repeat customers
    • Configure payment terms by customer
  4. Loyalty Program Setup:
    • Track customer purchase history
    • Automatically upgrade customers to VIP status
    • Set spending thresholds for tier advancement

üéØ Primary Vendor Strategy
Selecting Primary Vendors:
Criteria for Primary Vendor Selection:
  • Best Overall Value: Price + service + reliability
  • Consistent Availability: Stock levels and lead times
  • Geographic Coverage: Can deliver to all your service areas
  • Credit Terms: Favorable payment arrangements
  • Volume Discounts: Better pricing for bulk orders
Primary Vendor Examples by Trade:
  • HVAC: Ferguson HVAC Supply (equipment), Johnstone Supply (parts)
  • Plumbing: Ferguson Plumbing, Local plumbing supply house
  • Electrical: Graybar Electric, Local electrical wholesaler
  • General: Home Depot Pro, Menards Pro

üîÑ Backup Vendor Strategy
Why You Need Backup Vendors:
  • Stock Outages: Primary vendor runs out of critical items
  • Emergency Needs: Faster delivery when customer can't wait
  • Price Competition: Leverage for better primary vendor pricing
  • Quality Issues: Alternative source when problems arise
  • Geographic Coverage: Better local availability
Backup Vendor Selection Criteria:
  • Fast Delivery: Same-day or next-day availability
  • Local Presence: Will-call or nearby locations
  • Emergency Support: After-hours or weekend access
  • No Minimum Orders: Can buy single items when needed
Common Backup Vendor Examples:
Big Box Stores (Emergency/Small Quantities):
  • Home Depot - Basic materials, some equipment
  • Lowe's - Similar coverage to Home Depot
  • Menards - Regional availability with pro services
Local Suppliers (Relationship/Speed):
  • Local HVAC supply houses - Personal relationships
  • Electrical wholesalers - Specialized inventory
  • Plumbing suppliers - Local expertise
Online/Specialty (Hard-to-find items):
  • Amazon Business - Fast delivery, unique items
  • Grainger - Industrial supplies and tools
  • Specialty manufacturers - Direct from source
üéØ Specialized Vendor Categories
Equipment-Specific Vendors:
HVAC Equipment:
  • Carrier/Bryant: ICP parts and equipment
  • Trane: Direct from manufacturer
  • Rheem/Ruud: Factory parts and warranties
  • Goodman: Value equipment lines
Specialized Services:
  • Refrigerant Suppliers: Bulk refrigerant and recovery
  • Motor Shops: Custom motor repair and rewind
  • Fabrication Shops: Custom ductwork and sheet metal
  • Controls Specialists: Building automation systems
Service-Specific Vendor Setup:
Emergency Services:
  • 24/7 vendor hotlines
  • After-hours pickup arrangements
  • Emergency stock agreements
  • Premium pricing acknowledged
Large Projects:
  • Project-specific pricing
  • Staged delivery schedules
  • Job site delivery coordination
  • Extended payment terms
üìà Vendor Performance Tracking

Delivery Performance:
  • On-Time Delivery Rate: Target: 95%+ on-time
  • Order Accuracy: Target: 98%+ correct items
  • Damage Rate: Target: Less than 1% damaged goods
  • Lead Time Consistency: Promised vs. actual delivery
Financial Performance:
  • Price Competitiveness: Regular market comparisons
  • Payment Terms: Discount opportunities and flexibility
  • Invoice Accuracy: Billing errors and corrections
  • Volume Discounts: Achievement of tier pricing
Service Quality:
  • Communication: Response time to inquiries
  • Problem Resolution: Time to resolve issues
  • Product Knowledge: Staff expertise and helpfulness
  • Account Management: Proactive relationship management

What is a Pricebook? ‚ñº

A pricebook in ServiceTitan is your digital catalog of everything you can sell:

  • Services: What you do (install, repair, maintain)
  • Materials: Items consumed during work
  • Equipment: Items installed and left with customer

Why it matters: Consistent pricing, faster estimates, better profitability tracking!

Expected Time Investment:
  • Initial Setup: 2-4 hours for basic pricebook
  • Full Implementation: 1-2 days for comprehensive setup
  • Testing & Refinement: 1-2 weeks of real-world use
  • Team Training: 2-4 hours for technician onboarding

‚öôÔ∏è Setting Up the Service in ServiceTitan:

  1. Navigate to Pricebook: Settings ‚Üí Pricebook ‚Üí Services
  2. Create Category: Click "+ Add Category" if needed
  3. Add Service: Click "+ Add Service" in appropriate category
  4. Fill Basic Info: Name, SKU, description, labor hours
  5. Set Labor Pricing: Rate per hour or flat rate
  6. Add Materials: Click "+ Add Material" and search existing materials
  7. Add Equipment: Click "+ Add Equipment" and specify quantities
  8. Review Totals: Verify pricing calculations
  9. Save & Test: Create test estimate to verify

  6. Configure Details: SKU, description, unit of measure, cost
  7. Set Pricing: Cost markup or selling price
  8. Link Vendors: Connect to supplier information

4Connecting Materials & Equipment to Services

Step-by-Step: Adding Items to Services ‚ñº

üîó Complete Connection Process:

Step 1
Select Service
‚Üí
Step 2
Add Materials
‚Üí
Step 3
Add Equipment
‚Üí
Step 4
Review & Test
üìù Detailed Instructions:
  1. Navigate to Service:
    • Go to Settings ‚Üí Pricebook ‚Üí Services
    • Find your service or create new one
    • Click on service name to edit
  2. Add Materials Section:
    • Scroll to "Materials" section
    • Click "+ Add Material"
    • Search by name or SKU
    • Set quantity needed for service
    • Choose if material is "Required" or "Optional"
    • Add notes about usage (e.g., "Per linear foot")
  3. Add Equipment Section:
    • Scroll to "Equipment" section
    • Click "+ Add Equipment"
    • Select from equipment catalog
    • Specify quantity (usually 1 for major equipment)
    • Set as "Required" or let customer choose options
  4. Set Quantity Logic:
    • Fixed Quantity: Always uses same amount
    • Variable Quantity: Technician enters amount needed
    • Calculated Quantity: Based on job measurements
  5. Review Totals:
    • Verify total cost calculation
    • Check profit margins
    • Ensure pricing is competitive
  6. Save and Test:
    • Save service configuration
    • Create test estimate
    • Verify all items appear correctly
üí° Pro Tips:
  • Use "Required" for essential materials that every job needs
  • Use "Optional" for upgrades or customer choices
  • Add detailed notes for technician guidance
  • Group related materials together for easier selection

5Dynamic & Customer-Specific Pricing

üéØ What You'll Learn: How to set up automatic pricing rules that adjust based on conditions like customer type, job size, time of day, or market conditions.
Dynamic Pricing Rules - Complete Setup ‚ñº

üîÑ Types of Dynamic Pricing Rules:

‚è∞ Time-Based Pricing Rules
Rule Setup Examples:
After Hours (6 PM - 8 AM weekdays):
  • Condition: Time between 18:00-08:00 AND Monday-Friday
  • Adjustment: +25% on labor rates
  • Applied to: All services
  • Example: $150 service call becomes $187.50
Weekend Premium (All day Saturday-Sunday):
  • Condition: Saturday OR Sunday
  • Adjustment: +20% on total service
  • Applied to: Non-emergency services
  • Example: $500 repair becomes $600
Holiday Premium:
  • Condition: Major holidays (Memorial Day, July 4th, Labor Day, etc.)
  • Adjustment: +50% on all charges
  • Applied to: Emergency services only
  • Example: $200 emergency call becomes $300
‚è∞ Time-Based Pricing Calculator
üìä Volume-Based Pricing
Multi-Unit Discounts:
HVAC System Discounts:
  • 2 units: 5% discount
  • 3-4 units: 8% discount
  • 5+ units: 12% discount
Service Call Bundles:
  • Annual maintenance contract: 15% off individual services
  • Multiple systems serviced same day: 10% off additional units
Material Quantity Breaks:
  • Bulk materials (over $500): 5% discount
  • Large projects (over $2000): 8% material discount
üìä Volume Discount Calculator
Subtotal: $2500
Discount: 0%
Total: $2500
üö® Emergency Pricing
Emergency Classifications:
Same-Day Service:
  • Customer needs service within 4 hours
  • Adjustment: +30% on service charges
  • Applies to: All non-emergency services converted to urgent
True Emergency:
  • Safety hazard (gas leak, electrical danger, no heat in winter)
  • Adjustment: +40% on all charges
  • Applies to: Emergency service calls only
Weather-Related Emergency:
  • During storms, extreme temperatures, or natural disasters
  • Adjustment: +25-50% based on severity
  • Applies to: All emergency services during weather events
‚ö†Ô∏è Emergency Pricing Guidelines:
  • Clearly communicate emergency rates upfront
  • Document the emergency nature in service notes
  • Consider customer relationship and repeat business
  • Follow local regulations on emergency pricing
üå°Ô∏è Seasonal Adjustments
Peak Season Pricing:
Summer Peak (June-August):
  • AC services: +15% due to high demand
  • AC installations: +20% due to equipment shortage
  • Emergency cooling: +25% additional
Winter Peak (December-February):
  • Heating services: +15% due to high demand
  • Emergency heating: +30% during cold snaps
  • Furnace installations: +10% due to scheduling
Off-Season Discounts:
  • Spring/Fall maintenance: -10% to encourage preventive service
  • System installations during slow periods: -5%
üå°Ô∏è Seasonal Pricing Calculator
üìç Location-Based Pricing
Geographic Adjustments:
Travel Distance:
  • Within 15 miles: Standard pricing
  • 15-30 miles: +$25 travel charge
  • 30-50 miles: +$50 travel charge
  • Over 50 miles: +$75 + mileage
Market Areas:
  • High-income areas: +10% on services
  • Commercial districts: +15% for business hours
  • Rural areas: +$35 for extended travel time
Difficulty Factors:
  • High-rise buildings (over 3 floors): +20%
  • Difficult access locations: +15%
  • Restricted parking areas: +$25

‚öôÔ∏è Setting Up Dynamic Rules in ServiceTitan:

  1. Navigate to Pricing Rules: Settings ‚Üí Pricebook ‚Üí Pricing Rules
  2. Create New Rule: Click "+ Add Rule"
  3. Define Conditions:
    • Time-based: Set specific hours, days, or date ranges
    • Customer-based: Select customer types or specific customers
    • Service-based: Choose which services to apply rule to
    • Location-based: Set geographic boundaries
  4. Set Pricing Adjustment:
    • Percentage increase/decrease
    • Fixed dollar amount
    • New fixed price
  5. Define Scope:
    • Apply to labor only
    • Apply to materials only
    • Apply to entire service
    • Apply to specific categories
  6. Set Priority: If multiple rules apply, which takes precedence
  7. Test Scenarios: Create test estimates to verify rule behavior
Customer-Specific Pricing - Advanced Setup ‚ñº

üë• Customer Pricing Strategy:

üè¢ Commercial Customers
Property Management Companies:
  • Volume discount: 10-15% off standard rates
  • Annual contracts: Fixed pricing for 12 months
  • Payment terms: Net 30 days
  • Priority scheduling during business hours
Small Businesses:
  • Business hours discount: 5% off (less disruption)
  • Maintenance agreements: 20% off emergency calls
  • Bulk service packages available
üè† Residential Customers
VIP/Maintenance Members:
  • Service calls: 15% discount
  • Equipment installations: 10% discount
  • No trip charges
  • Priority scheduling
Senior Citizens:
  • Standard discount: 10% off services
  • Safety services: Additional discounts
  • Payment plans available
Military/First Responders:
  • Service discount: 10% off with valid ID
  • Emergency service priority
  • Flexible payment terms

üìã Setting Up Customer Types:

  1. Create Customer Categories:
    • Go to Settings ‚Üí Customers ‚Üí Customer Types
    • Add types: VIP, Commercial, Senior, Military, etc.
    • Set default discounts for each type
  2. Assign Pricing Rules:
    • Link customer types to specific pricing rules
    • Set automatic discount applications
    • Configure approval requirements for large discounts
  3. Individual Customer Overrides:
    • Set custom pricing for specific high-value customers
    • Create contract rates for repeat customers
    • Configure payment terms by customer
  4. Loyalty Program Setup:
    • Track customer purchase history
    • Automatically upgrade customers to VIP status
    • Set spending thresholds for tier advancement

üéØ Primary Vendor Strategy
Selecting Primary Vendors:
Criteria for Primary Vendor Selection:
  • Best Overall Value: Price + service + reliability
  • Consistent Availability: Stock levels and lead times
  • Geographic Coverage: Can deliver to all your service areas
  • Credit Terms: Favorable payment arrangements
  • Volume Discounts: Better pricing for bulk orders
Primary Vendor Examples by Trade:
  • HVAC: Ferguson HVAC Supply (equipment), Johnstone Supply (parts)
  • Plumbing: Ferguson Plumbing, Local plumbing supply house
  • Electrical: Graybar Electric, Local electrical wholesaler
  • General: Home Depot Pro, Menards Pro

üîÑ Backup Vendor Strategy
Why You Need Backup Vendors:
  • Stock Outages: Primary vendor runs out of critical items
  • Emergency Needs: Faster delivery when customer can't wait
  • Price Competition: Leverage for better primary vendor pricing
  • Quality Issues: Alternative source when problems arise
  • Geographic Coverage: Better local availability
Backup Vendor Selection Criteria:
  • Fast Delivery: Same-day or next-day availability
  • Local Presence: Will-call or nearby locations
  • Emergency Support: After-hours or weekend access
  • No Minimum Orders: Can buy single items when needed
Common Backup Vendor Examples:
Big Box Stores (Emergency/Small Quantities):
  • Home Depot - Basic materials, some equipment
  • Lowe's - Similar coverage to Home Depot
  • Menards - Regional availability with pro services
Local Suppliers (Relationship/Speed):
  • Local HVAC supply houses - Personal relationships
  • Electrical wholesalers - Specialized inventory
  • Plumbing suppliers - Local expertise
Online/Specialty (Hard-to-find items):
  • Amazon Business - Fast delivery, unique items
  • Grainger - Industrial supplies and tools
  • Specialty manufacturers - Direct from source
üéØ Specialized Vendor Categories
Equipment-Specific Vendors:
HVAC Equipment:
  • Carrier/Bryant: ICP parts and equipment
  • Trane: Direct from manufacturer
  • Rheem/Ruud: Factory parts and warranties
  • Goodman: Value equipment lines
Specialized Services:
  • Refrigerant Suppliers: Bulk refrigerant and recovery
  • Motor Shops: Custom motor repair and rewind
  • Fabrication Shops: Custom ductwork and sheet metal
  • Controls Specialists: Building automation systems
Service-Specific Vendor Setup:
Emergency Services:
  • 24/7 vendor hotlines
  • After-hours pickup arrangements
  • Emergency stock agreements
  • Premium pricing acknowledged
Large Projects:
  • Project-specific pricing
  • Staged delivery schedules
  • Job site delivery coordination
  • Extended payment terms
üìà Vendor Performance Tracking

Delivery Performance:
  • On-Time Delivery Rate: Target: 95%+ on-time
  • Order Accuracy: Target: 98%+ correct items
  • Damage Rate: Target: Less than 1% damaged goods
  • Lead Time Consistency: Promised vs. actual delivery
Financial Performance:
  • Price Competitiveness: Regular market comparisons
  • Payment Terms: Discount opportunities and flexibility
  • Invoice Accuracy: Billing errors and corrections
  • Volume Discounts: Achievement of tier pricing
Service Quality:
  • Communication: Response time to inquiries
  • Problem Resolution: Time to resolve issues

  • Account Management: Proactive relationship management

What is a Pricebook? ‚ñº

A pricebook in ServiceTitan is your digital catalog of everything you can sell:

  • Services: What you do (install, repair, maintain)
  • Materials: Items consumed during work
  • Equipment: Items installed and left with customer

Why it matters: Consistent pricing, faster estimates, better profitability tracking!

üìä Business Information Needed:

‚è∞ Time Allocation:

Expected Time Investment:
  • Initial Setup: 2-4 hours for basic pricebook
  • Full Implementation: 1-2 days for comprehensive setup
  • Testing & Refinement: 1-2 weeks of real-world use
  • Team Training: 2-4 hours for technician onboarding

4Connecting Materials & Equipment to Services

Step-by-Step: Adding Items to Services ‚ñº

üîó Complete Connection Process:

Step 1
Select Service
‚Üí
Step 2
Add Materials
‚Üí
Step 3
Add Equipment
‚Üí
Step 4
Review & Test
üìù Detailed Instructions:
  1. Navigate to Service:
    • Go to Settings ‚Üí Pricebook ‚Üí Services
    • Find your service or create new one
    • Click on service name to edit
  2. Add Materials Section:
    • Scroll to "Materials" section
    • Click "+ Add Material"
    • Search by name or SKU
    • Set quantity needed for service
    • Choose if material is "Required" or "Optional"
    • Add notes about usage (e.g., "Per linear foot")
  3. Add Equipment Section:
    • Scroll to "Equipment" section
    • Click "+ Add Equipment"
    • Select from equipment catalog
    • Specify quantity (usually 1 for major equipment)
    • Set as "Required" or let customer choose options
  4. Set Quantity Logic:
    • Fixed Quantity: Always uses same amount
    • Variable Quantity: Technician enters amount needed
    • Calculated Quantity: Based on job measurements
  5. Review Totals:
    • Verify total cost calculation
    • Check profit margins
    • Ensure pricing is competitive
  6. Save and Test:
    • Save service configuration
    • Create test estimate
    • Verify all items appear correctly
üí° Pro Tips:
  • Use "Required" for essential materials that every job needs
  • Use "Optional" for upgrades or customer choices
  • Add detailed notes for technician guidance
  • Group related materials together for easier selection

5Dynamic & Customer-Specific Pricing

üéØ What You'll Learn: How to set up automatic pricing rules that adjust based on conditions like customer type, job size, time of day, or market conditions.
Dynamic Pricing Rules - Complete Setup ‚ñº

üîÑ Types of Dynamic Pricing Rules:

‚è∞ Time-Based Pricing Rules
Rule Setup Examples:
After Hours (6 PM - 8 AM weekdays):
  • Condition: Time between 18:00-08:00 AND Monday-Friday
  • Adjustment: +25% on labor rates
  • Applied to: All services
  • Example: $150 service call becomes $187.50
Weekend Premium (All day Saturday-Sunday):
  • Condition: Saturday OR Sunday
  • Adjustment: +20% on total service
  • Applied to: Non-emergency services
  • Example: $500 repair becomes $600
Holiday Premium:
  • Condition: Major holidays (Memorial Day, July 4th, Labor Day, etc.)
  • Adjustment: +50% on all charges
  • Applied to: Emergency services only
  • Example: $200 emergency call becomes $300
‚è∞ Time-Based Pricing Calculator
üìä Volume-Based Pricing
Multi-Unit Discounts:
HVAC System Discounts:
  • 2 units: 5% discount
  • 3-4 units: 8% discount
  • 5+ units: 12% discount
Service Call Bundles:
  • Annual maintenance contract: 15% off individual services
  • Multiple systems serviced same day: 10% off additional units
Material Quantity Breaks:
  • Bulk materials (over $500): 5% discount
  • Large projects (over $2000): 8% material discount
üìä Volume Discount Calculator
Subtotal: $2500
Discount: 0%
Total: $2500
üö® Emergency Pricing
Emergency Classifications:
Same-Day Service:
  • Customer needs service within 4 hours
  • Adjustment: +30% on service charges
  • Applies to: All non-emergency services converted to urgent
True Emergency:
  • Safety hazard (gas leak, electrical danger, no heat in winter)
  • Adjustment: +40% on all charges
  • Applies to: Emergency service calls only
Weather-Related Emergency:
  • During storms, extreme temperatures, or natural disasters
  • Adjustment: +25-50% based on severity
  • Applies to: All emergency services during weather events
‚ö†Ô∏è Emergency Pricing Guidelines:
  • Clearly communicate emergency rates upfront
  • Document the emergency nature in service notes
  • Consider customer relationship and repeat business
  • Follow local regulations on emergency pricing
üå°Ô∏è Seasonal Adjustments
Peak Season Pricing:
Summer Peak (June-August):
  • AC services: +15% due to high demand
  • AC installations: +20% due to equipment shortage
  • Emergency cooling: +25% additional
Winter Peak (December-February):
  • Heating services: +15% due to high demand
  • Emergency heating: +30% during cold snaps
  • Furnace installations: +10% due to scheduling
Off-Season Discounts:
  • Spring/Fall maintenance: -10% to encourage preventive service
  • System installations during slow periods: -5%
üå°Ô∏è Seasonal Pricing Calculator
üìç Location-Based Pricing
Geographic Adjustments:
Travel Distance:
  • Within 15 miles: Standard pricing
  • 15-30 miles: +$25 travel charge
  • 30-50 miles: +$50 travel charge
  • Over 50 miles: +$75 + mileage
Market Areas:
  • High-income areas: +10% on services
  • Commercial districts: +15% for business hours
  • Rural areas: +$35 for extended travel time
Difficulty Factors:
  • High-rise buildings (over 3 floors): +20%
  • Difficult access locations: +15%
  • Restricted parking areas: +$25

‚öôÔ∏è Setting Up Dynamic Rules in ServiceTitan:

  1. Navigate to Pricing Rules: Settings ‚Üí Pricebook ‚Üí Pricing Rules
  2. Create New Rule: Click "+ Add Rule"
  3. Define Conditions:
    • Time-based: Set specific hours, days, or date ranges
    • Customer-based: Select customer types or specific customers
    • Service-based: Choose which services to apply rule to
    • Location-based: Set geographic boundaries
  4. Set Pricing Adjustment:
    • Percentage increase/decrease
    • Fixed dollar amount
    • New fixed price
  5. Define Scope:
    • Apply to labor only
    • Apply to materials only
    • Apply to entire service
    • Apply to specific categories
  6. Set Priority: If multiple rules apply, which takes precedence
  7. Test Scenarios: Create test estimates to verify rule behavior
Customer-Specific Pricing - Advanced Setup ‚ñº

üë• Customer Pricing Strategy:

üè¢ Commercial Customers
Property Management Companies:
  • Volume discount: 10-15% off standard rates
  • Annual contracts: Fixed pricing for 12 months
  • Payment terms: Net 30 days
  • Priority scheduling during business hours
Small Businesses:
  • Business hours discount: 5% off (less disruption)
  • Maintenance agreements: 20% off emergency calls
  • Bulk service packages available
üè† Residential Customers
VIP/Maintenance Members:
  • Service calls: 15% discount
  • Equipment installations: 10% discount
  • No trip charges
  • Priority scheduling
Senior Citizens:
  • Standard discount: 10% off services
  • Safety services: Additional discounts
  • Payment plans available
Military/First Responders:
  • Service discount: 10% off with valid ID
  • Emergency service priority
  • Flexible payment terms

üìã Setting Up Customer Types:

  1. Create Customer Categories:
    • Go to Settings ‚Üí Customers ‚Üí Customer Types
    • Add types: VIP, Commercial, Senior, Military, etc.
    • Set default discounts for each type
  2. Assign Pricing Rules:
    • Link customer types to specific pricing rules
    • Set automatic discount applications
    • Configure approval requirements for large discounts
  3. Individual Customer Overrides:
    • Set custom pricing for specific high-value customers
    • Create contract rates for repeat customers
    • Configure payment terms by customer
  4. Loyalty Program Setup:
    • Track customer purchase history
    • Automatically upgrade customers to VIP status
    • Set spending thresholds for tier advancement

  • Test all pricing rules thoroughly before going live
  • Ensure rules don't conflict with each other
  • Monitor profitability impact of all discounts
  • Train technicians on explaining pricing to customers
  • Review and adjust rules based on market feedback
