üéØ Primary Vendor Strategy
Selecting Primary Vendors:
Criteria for Primary Vendor Selection:
  • Best Overall Value: Price + service + reliability
  • Consistent Availability: Stock levels and lead times
  • Geographic Coverage: Can deliver to all your service areas
  • Credit Terms: Favorable payment arrangements
  • Volume Discounts: Better pricing for bulk orders
Primary Vendor Examples by Trade:
  • HVAC: Ferguson HVAC Supply (equipment), Johnstone Supply (parts)
  • Plumbing: Ferguson Plumbing, Local plumbing supply house
  • Electrical: Graybar Electric, Local electrical wholesaler
  • General: Home Depot Pro, Menards Pro

üîÑ Backup Vendor Strategy
Why You Need Backup Vendors:
  • Stock Outages: Primary vendor runs out of critical items
  • Emergency Needs: Faster delivery when customer can't wait
  • Price Competition: Leverage for better primary vendor pricing
  • Quality Issues: Alternative source when problems arise
  • Geographic Coverage: Better local availability
Backup Vendor Selection Criteria:
  • Fast Delivery: Same-day or next-day availability
  • Local Presence: Will-call or nearby locations
  • Emergency Support: After-hours or weekend access
  • No Minimum Orders: Can buy single items when needed
Common Backup Vendor Examples:
Big Box Stores (Emergency/Small Quantities):
  • Home Depot - Basic materials, some equipment
  • Lowe's - Similar coverage to Home Depot
  • Menards - Regional availability with pro services
Local Suppliers (Relationship/Speed):
  • Local HVAC supply houses - Personal relationships
  • Electrical wholesalers - Specialized inventory
  • Plumbing suppliers - Local expertise
Online/Specialty (Hard-to-find items):
  • Amazon Business - Fast delivery, unique items
  • Grainger - Industrial supplies and tools
  • Specialty manufacturers - Direct from source
üéØ Specialized Vendor Categories
Equipment-Specific Vendors:
HVAC Equipment:
  • Carrier/Bryant: ICP parts and equipment
  • Trane: Direct from manufacturer
  • Rheem/Ruud: Factory parts and warranties
  • Goodman: Value equipment lines
Specialized Services:
  • Refrigerant Suppliers: Bulk refrigerant and recovery
  • Motor Shops: Custom motor repair and rewind
  • Fabrication Shops: Custom ductwork and sheet metal
  • Controls Specialists: Building automation systems
Service-Specific Vendor Setup:
Emergency Services:
  • 24/7 vendor hotlines
  • After-hours pickup arrangements
  • Emergency stock agreements
  • Premium pricing acknowledged
Large Projects:
  • Project-specific pricing
  • Staged delivery schedules
  • Job site delivery coordination
  • Extended payment terms

Delivery Performance:
  • On-Time Delivery Rate: Target: 95%+ on-time

Financial Performance:
  • Price Competitiveness: Regular market comparisons
  • Payment Terms: Discount opportunities and flexibility
  • Invoice Accuracy: Billing errors and corrections
  • Volume Discounts: Achievement of tier pricing

  • Communication: Response time to inquiries

A pricebook in ServiceTitan is your digital catalog of everything you can sell:

  • Services: What you do (install, repair, maintain)
  • Materials: Items consumed during work
  • Equipment: Items installed and left with customer

Why it matters: Consistent pricing, faster estimates, better profitability tracking!

  • 200A Main Panel (24 circuit) - $320
  • 200A Meter Socket - $85
  • 200A Main Breaker - $65
Total Equipment: $470
üí∞ Service Pricing Summary:
Labor: $1,050 + Materials: $440 + Equipment: $470 = $1,960 Cost
With 45% markup: $2,842 Service Price

‚öôÔ∏è Setting Up the Service in ServiceTitan:

  1. Navigate to Pricebook: Settings ‚Üí Pricebook ‚Üí Services
  2. Create Category: Click "+ Add Category" if needed
  3. Add Service: Click "+ Add Service" in appropriate category
  4. Fill Basic Info: Name, SKU, description, labor hours
  5. Set Labor Pricing: Rate per hour or flat rate
  6. Add Materials: Click "+ Add Material" and search existing materials
  7. Add Equipment: Click "+ Add Equipment" and specify quantities
  8. Review Totals: Verify pricing calculations
  9. Save & Test: Create test estimate to verify

4Connecting Materials & Equipment to Services

Step-by-Step: Adding Items to Services ‚ñº

üîó Complete Connection Process:

Step 1
Select Service
‚Üí
Step 2
Add Materials
‚Üí
Step 3
Add Equipment
‚Üí
Step 4
Review & Test
üìù Detailed Instructions:
  1. Navigate to Service:
    • Go to Settings ‚Üí Pricebook ‚Üí Services
    • Find your service or create new one
    • Click on service name to edit
  2. Add Materials Section:
    • Scroll to "Materials" section
    • Click "+ Add Material"
    • Search by name or SKU
    • Set quantity needed for service
    • Choose if material is "Required" or "Optional"
    • Add notes about usage (e.g., "Per linear foot")
  3. Add Equipment Section:
    • Scroll to "Equipment" section
    • Click "+ Add Equipment"
    • Select from equipment catalog
    • Specify quantity (usually 1 for major equipment)
    • Set as "Required" or let customer choose options
  4. Set Quantity Logic:
    • Fixed Quantity: Always uses same amount
    • Variable Quantity: Technician enters amount needed
    • Calculated Quantity: Based on job measurements
  5. Review Totals:
    • Verify total cost calculation
    • Check profit margins
    • Ensure pricing is competitive
  6. Save and Test:
    • Save service configuration
    • Create test estimate
    • Verify all items appear correctly
üí° Pro Tips:
  • Use "Required" for essential materials that every job needs
  • Use "Optional" for upgrades or customer choices
  • Add detailed notes for technician guidance
  • Group related materials together for easier selection

5Dynamic & Customer-Specific Pricing

üéØ What You'll Learn: How to set up automatic pricing rules that adjust based on conditions like customer type, job size, time of day, or market conditions.
Dynamic Pricing Rules - Complete Setup ‚ñº

üîÑ Types of Dynamic Pricing Rules:

‚è∞ Time-Based Pricing Rules
Rule Setup Examples:
After Hours (6 PM - 8 AM weekdays):
  • Condition: Time between 18:00-08:00 AND Monday-Friday
  • Adjustment: +25% on labor rates
  • Applied to: All services
  • Example: $150 service call becomes $187.50
Weekend Premium (All day Saturday-Sunday):
  • Condition: Saturday OR Sunday
  • Adjustment: +20% on total service
  • Applied to: Non-emergency services
  • Example: $500 repair becomes $600
Holiday Premium:
  • Condition: Major holidays (Memorial Day, July 4th, Labor Day, etc.)
  • Adjustment: +50% on all charges
  • Applied to: Emergency services only
  • Example: $200 emergency call becomes $300
‚è∞ Time-Based Pricing Calculator
üìä Volume-Based Pricing
Multi-Unit Discounts:
HVAC System Discounts:
  • 2 units: 5% discount
  • 3-4 units: 8% discount
  • 5+ units: 12% discount
Service Call Bundles:
  • Annual maintenance contract: 15% off individual services
  • Multiple systems serviced same day: 10% off additional units
Material Quantity Breaks:
  • Bulk materials (over $500): 5% discount
  • Large projects (over $2000): 8% material discount
üìä Volume Discount Calculator
Subtotal: $2500
Discount: 0%
Total: $2500
üö® Emergency Pricing
Emergency Classifications:
Same-Day Service:
  • Customer needs service within 4 hours
  • Adjustment: +30% on service charges
  • Applies to: All non-emergency services converted to urgent
True Emergency:
  • Safety hazard (gas leak, electrical danger, no heat in winter)
  • Adjustment: +40% on all charges
  • Applies to: Emergency service calls only
Weather-Related Emergency:
  • During storms, extreme temperatures, or natural disasters
  • Adjustment: +25-50% based on severity
  • Applies to: All emergency services during weather events
‚ö†Ô∏è Emergency Pricing Guidelines:
  • Clearly communicate emergency rates upfront
  • Document the emergency nature in service notes
  • Consider customer relationship and repeat business
  • Follow local regulations on emergency pricing
üå°Ô∏è Seasonal Adjustments
Peak Season Pricing:
Summer Peak (June-August):
  • AC services: +15% due to high demand
  • AC installations: +20% due to equipment shortage
  • Emergency cooling: +25% additional
Winter Peak (December-February):
  • Heating services: +15% due to high demand
  • Emergency heating: +30% during cold snaps
  • Furnace installations: +10% due to scheduling
Off-Season Discounts:
  • Spring/Fall maintenance: -10% to encourage preventive service
  • System installations during slow periods: -5%
üå°Ô∏è Seasonal Pricing Calculator
üìç Location-Based Pricing
Geographic Adjustments:
Travel Distance:
  • Within 15 miles: Standard pricing
  • 15-30 miles: +$25 travel charge
  • 30-50 miles: +$50 travel charge
  • Over 50 miles: +$75 + mileage
Market Areas:
  • High-income areas: +10% on services
  • Commercial districts: +15% for business hours
  • Rural areas: +$35 for extended travel time
Difficulty Factors:
  • High-rise buildings (over 3 floors): +20%
  • Difficult access locations: +15%
  • Restricted parking areas: +$25

‚öôÔ∏è Setting Up Dynamic Rules in ServiceTitan:

  1. Navigate to Pricing Rules: Settings ‚Üí Pricebook ‚Üí Pricing Rules
  2. Create New Rule: Click "+ Add Rule"
  3. Define Conditions:
    • Time-based: Set specific hours, days, or date ranges
    • Customer-based: Select customer types or specific customers
    • Service-based: Choose which services to apply rule to
    • Location-based: Set geographic boundaries
  4. Set Pricing Adjustment:
    • Percentage increase/decrease
    • Fixed dollar amount
    • New fixed price
  5. Define Scope:
    • Apply to labor only
    • Apply to materials only
    • Apply to entire service
    • Apply to specific categories
  6. Set Priority: If multiple rules apply, which takes precedence
  7. Test Scenarios: Create test estimates to verify rule behavior
Customer-Specific Pricing - Advanced Setup ‚ñº

üë• Customer Pricing Strategy:

üè¢ Commercial Customers
Property Management Companies:
  • Volume discount: 10-15% off standard rates
  • Annual contracts: Fixed pricing for 12 months
  • Payment terms: Net 30 days
  • Priority scheduling during business hours
Small Businesses:
  • Business hours discount: 5% off (less disruption)
  • Maintenance agreements: 20% off emergency calls
  • Bulk service packages available
üè† Residential Customers
VIP/Maintenance Members:
  • Service calls: 15% discount
  • Equipment installations: 10% discount
  • No trip charges
  • Priority scheduling
Senior Citizens:
  • Standard discount: 10% off services
  • Safety services: Additional discounts
  • Payment plans available
Military/First Responders:
  • Service discount: 10% off with valid ID
  • Emergency service priority
  • Flexible payment terms

üìã Setting Up Customer Types:

  1. Create Customer Categories:
    • Go to Settings ‚Üí Customers ‚Üí Customer Types
    • Add types: VIP, Commercial, Senior, Military, etc.
    • Set default discounts for each type
  2. Assign Pricing Rules:
    • Link customer types to specific pricing rules
    • Set automatic discount applications
    • Configure approval requirements for large discounts
  3. Individual Customer Overrides:
    • Set custom pricing for specific high-value customers
    • Create contract rates for repeat customers
    • Configure payment terms by customer
  4. Loyalty Program Setup:
    • Track customer purchase history
    • Automatically upgrade customers to VIP status
    • Set spending thresholds for tier advancement

üí° Best Practices:
  • Document all customer agreements in writing
  • Review customer pricing annually
  • Track profitability by customer type
  • Train staff on when to apply discounts
  • Set clear approval processes for custom pricing
‚ö†Ô∏è Important Considerations:
  • Test all pricing rules thoroughly before going live
  • Ensure rules don't conflict with each other
  • Monitor profitability impact of all discounts
  • Train technicians on explaining pricing to customers
  • Review and adjust rules based on market feedback

üéØ Primary Vendor Strategy

  • Volume Discounts: Better pricing for bulk orders
Primary Vendor Examples by Trade:
  • HVAC: Ferguson HVAC Supply (equipment), Johnstone Supply (parts)
  • Plumbing: Ferguson Plumbing, Local plumbing supply house
  • Electrical: Graybar Electric, Local electrical wholesaler
  • General: Home Depot Pro, Menards Pro

üîÑ Backup Vendor Strategy
Why You Need Backup Vendors:
  • Stock Outages: Primary vendor runs out of critical items
  • Emergency Needs: Faster delivery when customer can't wait
  • Price Competition: Leverage for better primary vendor pricing
  • Quality Issues: Alternative source when problems arise
  • Geographic Coverage: Better local availability
Backup Vendor Selection Criteria:
  • Fast Delivery: Same-day or next-day availability
  • Local Presence: Will-call or nearby locations
  • Emergency Support: After-hours or weekend access
  • No Minimum Orders: Can buy single items when needed
Common Backup Vendor Examples:
Big Box Stores (Emergency/Small Quantities):
  • Home Depot - Basic materials, some equipment
  • Lowe's - Similar coverage to Home Depot
  • Menards - Regional availability with pro services
Local Suppliers (Relationship/Speed):
  • Local HVAC supply houses - Personal relationships
  • Electrical wholesalers - Specialized inventory
  • Plumbing suppliers - Local expertise
Online/Specialty (Hard-to-find items):
  • Amazon Business - Fast delivery, unique items
  • Grainger - Industrial supplies and tools
  • Specialty manufacturers - Direct from source
üéØ Specialized Vendor Categories
Equipment-Specific Vendors:
HVAC Equipment:
  • Carrier/Bryant: ICP parts and equipment
  • Trane: Direct from manufacturer
  • Rheem/Ruud: Factory parts and warranties
  • Goodman: Value equipment lines
Specialized Services:
  • Refrigerant Suppliers: Bulk refrigerant and recovery
  • Motor Shops: Custom motor repair and rewind
  • Fabrication Shops: Custom ductwork and sheet metal
  • Controls Specialists: Building automation systems
Service-Specific Vendor Setup:
Emergency Services:
  • 24/7 vendor hotlines
  • After-hours pickup arrangements
  • Emergency stock agreements
  • Premium pricing acknowledged
Large Projects:
  • Project-specific pricing
  • Staged delivery schedules
  • Job site delivery coordination
  • Extended payment terms
üìà Vendor Performance Tracking
Key Performance Indicators (KPIs):
Delivery Performance:
  • On-Time Delivery Rate: Target: 95%+ on-time
  • Order Accuracy: Target: 98%+ correct items
  • Damage Rate: Target: Less than 1% damaged goods
  • Lead Time Consistency: Promised vs. actual delivery
Financial Performance:
  • Price Competitiveness: Regular market comparisons
  • Payment Terms: Discount opportunities and flexibility
  • Invoice Accuracy: Billing errors and corrections
  • Volume Discounts: Achievement of tier pricing
Service Quality:
  • Communication: Response time to inquiries
  • Problem Resolution: Time to resolve issues
  • Product Knowledge: Staff expertise and helpfulness
  • Account Management: Proactive relationship management
